Name: Petty Cash
Description: Petty cash is the amount of ready cash that the practice keeps available on premises for incidental needs. Examples of petty cash uses include reimbursement to employees for out-of-pocket purchases of office supplies and postage.

Name: Cash in Daily Drawer
Description: The cash drawer represents the amount of cash on hand to provide change to clients, who are making cash purchases of services and retail items, or are settling the balances of their accounts. A separate petty cash fund should be maintained for incidental expenses.

Name: Undeposited Funds
Description: This account records client payments and other receipts on premises or otherwise under practice control, and not yet deposited to the bank.

Name: Primary Checking Account
Description: The chief operating bank account used for daily fee collection deposits and for paying bills.

Name: Secondary Checking Account
Description: Many practices maintain more than one checking account, such as an account for payroll or an account that reflects the activity of a second practice location.

Name: Savings Account
Description: In general, a practice savings account serves as an interest-bearing repository of reserve funds for working-capital requirements or for planned investments or commitments such as employee retirement funding.

Name: Certificates of Deposit
Description: Record investments in certificate of deposits to this account. Interest earned on investments will be recorded in the 9050 account for interest revenues either at the time the interest is received (cash basis accounting) or when the right to it is earned (accrual basis accounting).

Name: Money Market Account
Description: Either a commercial bank’s account or a brokerage-held account, a practice money market account provides another interest-bearing option for reserving funds to meet working capital needs or for future practice commitments.

Name: Accounts Receivable
Description: The account used for recording client-owed amounts for veterinary services and ancillary purchases.

Name: Allowance for Uncollectable Accounts (contra account)
Description: This is a contra asset account associated with accounts receivable. This account will maintain a credit balance and should be used when anticipating a portion of the accounts receivable will be uncollectible in the future.

Name: Drug and Medical Supply Inventory
Description: Inventory value should be a reasonable approximation of drugs on hand (at acquisition cost) at quarterly reporting dates, including partial packages.

Name: Employee Advances
Description: Advances to employees, most often as very short-term loans against future wages are recorded in this account.

Name: Advances -- Related Party
Description: This account is used to record episodic and quickly repaid personal expenditures made on behalf of officers or owners of the practice.

Name: Note Receivable, Current Portion -- Related Party
Description: Notes receivable usually reflect an interest-bearing loan of a large money amount or sale of valuable company property to an individual, with the requirement for repayment of the amount or value. If the terms of the loan provide for repayment to the practice over a period of longer than one year, then the portion to be repaid in greater than twelve months’ time is recorded in account 2600, Long Term Portion of Notes Receivable. Account 1500 is explicitly reserved for amounts loaned to individuals who are related to the practice through ownership rights or through fiduciary responsibility, such as a director or officer.

Name: Note Receivable, Current Portion -- Other
Description: This account carries amounts owed to the practice, usually by non-owner employees or related entities. Occasionally, it will also include client-signed promissory notes made to the practice when the client has renegotiated large, outstanding accounts-receivable amounts for documented re-payment over time.

Name: Prepaid Expenses
Description: Record in this account any payments that reflect the acquisition of services that the practice will use in a future financial period. In the financial period of their use, adjust prepaid amounts as expenses and reduces the asset value of the prepaid expense account. Some examples of prepaid expenses are airline tickets and convention registration purchased for a continuing education event scheduled some months in the future; professional dues and membership payments for a future membership period; and service contracts that cover one or several years of future financial periods. Include in this account prepaid insurance premiums, prepaid rent, prepaid federal income tax, prepaid state income and/or franchise tax, and prepaid local income tax if applicable to your practice.

Name: Prepaid Interest
Description: Record in this account any payments that reflect the prepayment of interest to be expensed in future periods

Name: Deposits for New Equipment
Description: Record in this account any down payments made for equipment orders and similar assets that will be received and put in service at a future date.

Name: Construction In Progress
Description: When the practice is renovating or expanding facility or constructing other capital assets that have not yet been put into service, payments made for the ongoing construction project are coded here. Once the project is complete, and all costs have been accumulated, the total is re-classed to the appropriate fixed asset accounts with adequately detailed descriptions. When the building or constructed asset is put in service, depreciation can begin.

Name: Professional Medical Equipment
Description: The acquisition costs of all medical, surgical, and diagnostic equipment used for service provision and revenue generation are included in this account. Examples include autoclaves and sterilization equipment; surgery and anesthetic equipment; X-ray machines and other imaging equipment such as ultrasound machines; microscopes and bench laboratory machines; and any other type of medical, patient-support, or monitoring equipment. Any item of equipment to which the practice has title or realistically will have title through acquisition contract terms should be listed in this account.

Name: Computer Hardware
Description: Record all purchased computer equipment in this account, including electronic office equipment such as electronic cash registers, computer peripheral equipment, modems, surge protectors, computer cabling, servers, video monitors, printers, fax machines and network copiers. As the practice takes computer equipment out of service (often due to obsolescence as much as to breakage), it should also dispose of and remove the equipment from the accounting records.

Name: Office Equipment, Furniture & Fixtures
Description: This fixed asset account includes all non-computer office equipment acquisitions, such as phone systems, calculators, photocopiers (not computer-networked), typewriters, paper-shredders, and similar equipment. It also includes appliances such as washers, dryers, freezers, and TVs not associated with medical equipment. The account also includes office furnishings such as desks, filing cabinets, chairs, waiting room furniture, decor, lockers, bookcases, movable lighting fixtures, signs, and other appurtenances not permanently affixed and integral features of the building.

Name: Practice Vehicles
Description: Vehicles owned by and titled to the practice are coded in this account, and in general are used in the production of veterinary revenue (patient transport, house calls, business errands and travel). Debatable issues affecting appropriate accounting for leased vehicles dictate you seek the practice accountant’s input and advice so that regulatory compliance occurs. Additionally, vehicles used in companion animal practice may have mixed use for personal use and commuting, as well as for the purposes of conducting veterinary business. Once business use (which does NOT include commuting) falls below 50%, special rules apply to depreciation.

Name: Leasehold/Building Improvements
Description: Code building construction projects that upgrade and/or extend the useful life of practice-occupied buildings in this account. Integral, stationary, and permanently affixed parts of the facility, building improvements increase its value and usefulness. Improvements include renovations, additions, permanent upgrades, new roofs, and new floors. Capitalize major repairs, which add significant facility value or life expectancy, for inclusion in this account.

Name: Buildings
Description: Record any costs of buildings to which the practice holds ownership title in this account.

Name: Land Improvements
Description: Improvements made to land owned or leased by the practice, which includes such enhancements as driveways, sidewalks, landscaping, storm drainage, utilities, and septic systems.

Name: Land
Description: Record in this account the cost of any land purchased by the practice, to which it takes title (an estate in real property). As a non-wasting asset, land is not depreciated. As such, no accumulated depreciation account exists for this fixed asset.

Name: Accumulated Depreciation (contra account)
Description: This is a general “catch-all” account for use in recording accumulated depreciation for all depreciable assets, in the event the practice owners (or accountant) prefers not to group accumulated depreciation with its related asset classes (professional equipment, office equipment, etc.) This provides an expedited method for tracking accumulated depreciation in a single balance sheet account.

Name: Computer Software
Description: Computer software purchases are capitalized and recorded in this account. Often, computer software is bundled as part of a computer system purchase. The portion of the purchase price attributable to software is identified and recorded in this account. Since tax rules change about the correct way to depreciate or amortize software, speak with the practice’s accountant to decide the best way to record system purchases which include both hardware and software components.

Name: Goodwill
Description: Goodwill recorded in the practice books depends on the fact of a transaction involving goodwill acquisition at some time in the entity’s history. Goodwill represents the amount paid for an existing practice entity (target) that is in excess of the target’s other assets at the time of purchase. This account is only used for recording the purchase of preexisting goodwill from another entity.

Name: Covenant Not to Compete
Description: The negotiated price assigned to the covenant not to compete in the course of allocating the total practice purchase is recorded in this account.

Name: Organizational & Startup costs
Description: Costs related to veterinary practice start up and organization are capitalized and recorded to this account, including legal, accounting, site selection, appraisals, and any other fees incurred prior to the actual opening of the doors for business.

Name: Loan Costs
Description: Loan costs should be amortized over the life of the loan. Fees such as legal, accounting, registration and bank fees incurred in conjunction with obtaining or refinancing a loan are considered loan fees. Record all such loan fees in this account and amortize them by debiting amortization expense account 8050 and crediting 2599 Accumulated Amortization monthly over the life of the loan.

Name: Accumulated Amortization
Description: This is a general “catch-all” account for use in recording accumulated amortization for all intangible and amortizable assets. This provides an expedited method for tracking accumulated amortization in a single balance sheet account.

Name: Note Receivable, Long-Term Portion
Description: This account reflects the principle portion of promissory notes and secured notes for which receipt occurs at greater than twelve months from the balance sheet date. Adjust the note’s current portion, that is, the principal amount receivable in 12 months or less, in accounts 1450 or 1500.

Name: Refundable Deposits
Description: Use this account to record the amount of refundable deposits made at the initiation of a service, such as utilities. If the deposit is non-refundable, then it should be expensed when the expenditure occurred.

Name: Other Assets
Description: Include in this account the cash value of any practice-owned life insurance policy or other assets not specified in listed asset accounts.

Name: Accounts Payable
Description: Code amounts owed to vendors for purchases made on credit. Such purchases are made to acquire the supplies, services, and materials needed for the practice of veterinary medicine. This account is a control account for a subsidiary ledger of each vendor, the amounts owed to that vendor, and aged amount of the payable (showing whether the payable amounts are current, or represent credit purchases that occurred 30, 60, 90, or more days in the past).

Name: Credit Cards Payable
Description: This account represents all purchases made through the use of a credit card.

Name: Line of Credit
Description: The balance in this account represents total amount outstanding on the line of credit at any one time.

Name: Long-Term Loans & Capital Leases Payable, Current Portion
Description: Practice debt contracted for payment over a period greater than one year is posted to two accounts. Record the loan principal portion due in less than twelve months to this account. Account for the principal portions of loans due in greater than twelve months in the 3800 series. Adjustments to long- and short-term portions are typically made at the end of the accounting period.

Name: Loan Payable, Current Portion -- Related Party
Description: An officer or owner may loan money to the practice from time to time. This account represents the amount owed to the related party that will be repaid within one year. If the loan will extend beyond twelve months, then the loan should be accounted for as to the long-term and short-term portions.

Name: Unearned Revenue
Description: This account represents a liability account to record payments received in advance of providing goods or services. A typical example of unearned revenue in a practice would be related to wellness plans where payments are received by a hospital before goods or services are provided. As goods and services are provided, the bookkeeper should debit this account and credit the appropriate revenue category.

Name: Rent Payable
Description: This account contains any rent that has been incurred/expensed, but not yet paid, and is due within 30 days

Name: Payroll Tax Payable
Description: Include in this account employer FICA tax which consists of Medicare and OASDI (Old Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance). The employer’s FICA obligation is recorded here, as the amount that must be remitted to the IRS coincident with the remittance of FICA payroll tax withholding from employee wages for a recently paid payroll. Include in this account federal unemployment tax payable which includes the balance of federal unemployment tax accrued on previously paid wages but not yet paid to the IRS. Include in this account state unemployment tax payable which reflects state unemployment tax accrued on previously paid wages but not yet paid to the state agency.

Name: Wage Garnishment Payable
Description: This account carries the balance of any garnished wage expense that was not paid to the employee, but rather held for payment to a third party as required by a government entity and/or court of law.

Name: Workers Compensation Payable
Description: This account reflects workers compensation premiums payable but not yet remitted to the insurer. Workers compensation premium cost is considered a tax (rather than insurance) by many accountants, as it is not a voluntary payment but a legally mandated one when an employer has employees.

Name: Accrued Payroll & Bonuses
Description: The value of employee work time that has occurred but the practice will not pay until the next payroll date is said to be accrued. The practice incurs a liability to pay the employee for his or her time, but the pay period has not yet completely run, so is not due for payment. For accrual-based practices, this account generally carries a balance at the fiscal year end, when workers have wages due to them for hours worked, that the practice will not pay until the pay date falling in the first or second week of the following year. The value of any holiday, personal, or sick time earned by employees and not yet paid is carried in this account. Cash basis practices will generally not use this account.

Name: Accrued Payroll Taxes
Description: This account carries the outstanding balance of employer payroll tax obligations associated with accrued wages and accrued paid time off (account 3150). It generally includes only the employer’s portion of FICA tax, federal unemployment tax, and state unemployment tax associated with accrued wages and salary obligations. Like accrued payroll, generally only accrual based accounting method companies use this account.

Name: Employer Retirement Plan Contribution Payable
Description: This account carries the balance of previously committed, but not yet paid, contributions to the employer-sponsored retirement plan in accord with the plan document’s requirements. Many plans allow the employer to take a deduction for the committed amount in the year to which it pertains, whether paid or not, and regardless of whether the practice is cash or accrual based for tax purposes. The practice generally has until the extended due date of the federal tax return to pay the funding obligation.

Name: Employee Payroll Tax Withholding Payable
Description: This account carries the balance of federal income tax withheld from employee wages that has not yet been paid to the IRS. The federal income taxes withheld and remitted by the employer on the employee’s behalf do not belong to the employer. The employer functions as an agent of the government to assure the timely remittance of employee tax payments through forced withholding by the employer.

Name: Employee Withholding Payable
Description: From time to time, some employees will experience court-ordered wage withholdings that are designated for use by some agency. In accord with the court order, the practice withholds the required amount and forwards it to the requisite agency on the employee’s behalf. The balance carried in this account represents all withholdings not yet remitted to the agencies.

Name: Employee Benefit Plan Deferrals (401(k), etc) Payable
Sales & Use Tax Payable, Current Portion
Description: Many states require businesses to collect sales tax from consumers when they make purchases. When the practice collects sales tax from its clients at point of sale, the tax amount is credited to this account until the time the practice remits all collected tax amounts to the state. The requirements are comparable to payroll tax withholding rules: the state requires the practice to function as its agent, by collecting the appropriate amount of tax on subject sales and remitting it to the state revenue department.

Name: Accrued Property Tax -- Current Portion
Description: If the practice owns real estate or is obligated through the lease agreement to pay taxes on the real estate, post the amount due and not yet paid to this account. Some states tax the value of personal property, either tangible property or intangible property or both. Accrual-based practices use this account to record the amount due and not yet paid.

Name: Corporate Income Tax Payable -- Current Portion
Description: Both cash-basis and accrual-basis corporations use this account to record the amount of federal income tax owed for the most recently completed tax year. In general, the account only pertains to Subchapter C Corporations and Personal Service Corporations. All other legal entity types allow taxable practice income to pass through to individual owners for reporting on their personal tax returns. This account records any practice-owed income tax at the state, city, local or regional level that has not yet been paid.

Name: Franchise Tax Payable, Current Portion
Description: Some states and many local jursidictions require businesses to pay a total revenues-based tax, typically calculated and remitted annually.

Name: Loans & Capital Leases Payable, Long-Term Portion
Description: Record the principal portion of loans scheduled for repayment over a period greater than one year. Such loans will have terms that include a stated principal amount, monthly payment amount, and a stated interest rate. The current portion of the debt, the principal portion that will be repaid within a calendar or fiscal year, will be reported in account 3030. Most common long-term debt examples include mortgages and equipment loans with repayment schedules spanning multiple years. Also known as a purchase lease, a capital lease provides for transferred title of ownership to the lessee at the end of the lease term, usually for some bargain price such as one dollar. This account maintains the principal balance that is due in greater than twelve months from the balance sheet report date. The current portion of a capital lease is reported in account 3030.

Name: Loan Payable -- Related Party
Description: Record the principal portion of loans from related parties scheduled for repayment over a period greater than one year. Such loans will have terms that include a stated principal amount, monthly payment amount, and a stated interest rate. The current portion of the debt, the principal portion that will be repaid within a calendar or fiscal year, will be reported in account 3030. Most common long-term debt examples include mortgages and equipment loans with repayment schedules spanning multiple years. Also known as a purchase lease, a capital lease provides for transferred title of ownership to the lessee at the end of the lease term, usually for some bargain price such as one dollar. This account maintains the principal balance that is due in greater than twelve months from the balance sheet report date. The current portion of a capital lease is reported in account 3030.

Name: Sales & Use Tax Payable, Long-Term Portion
Description: Many states require businesses to collect sales tax from consumers when they make purchases. When the practice collects sales tax from its clients at point of sale, the tax amount is credited to this account until the time the practice remits all collected tax amounts to the state. The requirements are comparable to payroll tax withholding rules: the state requires the practice to function as its agent, by collecting the appropriate amount of tax on subject sales and remitting it to the state revenue department.

Name: Accrued Property Tax -- Long-Term Portion
Description: If the practice owns real estate or is obligated through the lease agreement to pay taxes on the real estate, post the amount due and not yet paid to this account. Some states tax the value of personal property, either tangible property or intangible property or both. Accrual-based practices use this account to record the amount due and not yet paid.

Name: Corporate Income Tax Payable -- Long-Term Portion
Description: Both cash-basis and accrual-basis corporations use this account to record the amount of federal income tax owed for the most recently completed tax year. In general, the account only pertains to Subchapter C Corporations and Personal Service Corporations. All other legal entity types allow taxable practice income to pass through to individual owners for reporting on their personal tax returns. This account records any practice-owed income tax at the state, city, local or regional level that has not yet been paid.

Name: Common Stock (C-Corp)
Description: This account title pertains to practices functioning in any of the corporate formats. The account balance reflects the value of issued and outstanding shares of corporate stock, usually at their original stated value. This is an account that infrequently changes, so it is likely any adjustments will come from the practice’s accountant as a result of significant transaction events related to practice ownership. Often, the only transaction shown in the account occurs at the inception of the corporation when it issues shares to the first shareholders.

Name: Additional Paid in Capital  (C-Corp)
Description: Record any capital paid by shareholders to the corporation in excess of the stated share value. Generally, this account is used very infrequently, often only at the corporation’s inception when it issues stock to the new shareholders in exchange for money and property. Any value in excess of the stated share value, which can be found in the original articles of incorporation, is recorded as additional paid in capital (commonly abbreviated APIC).

Name: Retained Earnings / (Deficit)  (C-Corp)
Description: This account reflects a practice’s accumulated profits and losses over time, which have not been distributed to owners. The account is presented separately from the Common Stock and Additional Paid in Capital accounts because it derives its balances from operational results, not from financing.

Name: Distributions/Dividends/Draws  (C-Corp)
Description: Any dividends (Subchapter C or a personal service corporation (PSC)) or distributions (Subchapter S Corporation) are recorded here during the fiscal year. At the beginning of the subsequent fiscal year, all dividends and distributions are closed by an account adjustment to Retained Earnings/(Deficit), account 4200. Withdrawals by members of an unincorporated entity will be booked to this account, also. Modify the account title to reflect the entity type: Owner Draws, Partner Draws, or Member Draws.

Name: Treasury Stock  (C-Corp)
Description: Treasury stock is the amount of previously issued stock subsequently redeemed and held by the corporation. This situation usually occurs when a shareholder retires from the practice and sells his shares back to the corporation rather than to another individual. When the corporation purchases its own shares from the departing shareholder, the shares are said to be in the treasury.

Name: Common Stock  (S-Corp)
Description: This account title pertains to practices functioning in any of the corporate formats. The account balance reflects the value of issued and outstanding shares of corporate stock, usually at their original stated value. This is an account that infrequently changes, so it is likely any adjustments will come from the practice’s accountant as a result of significant transaction events related to practice ownership. Often, the only transaction shown in the account occurs at the inception of the corporation when it issues shares to the first shareholders.

Name: Additional Paid in Capital  (S-Corp)
Description: Record any capital paid by shareholders to the corporation in excess of the stated share value. Generally, this account is used very infrequently, often only at the corporation’s inception when it issues stock to the new shareholders in exchange for money and property. Any value in excess of the stated share value, which can be found in the original articles of incorporation, is recorded as additional paid in capital (commonly abbreviated APIC).

Name: Retained Earnings / (Deficit)  (S-Corp)
Description: This account reflects a practice’s accumulated profits and losses over time, which have not been distributed to owners. The account is presented separately from the Common Stock and Additional Paid in Capital accounts because it derives its balances from operational results, not from financing.

Name: Distributions/Dividends/Draws  (S-Corp)
Description: Any dividends (Subchapter C or a personal service corporation (PSC)) or distributions (Subchapter S Corporation) are recorded here during the fiscal year. At the beginning of the subsequent fiscal year, all dividends and distributions are closed by an account adjustment to Retained Earnings/(Deficit), account 4200. Withdrawals by members of an unincorporated entity will be booked to this account, also. Modify the account title to reflect the entity type: Owner Draws, Partner Draws, or Member Draws.

Name: Treasury Stock  (S-Corp)
Description: Treasury stock is the amount of previously issued stock subsequently redeemed and held by the corporation. This situation usually occurs when a shareholder retires from the practice and sells his shares back to the corporation rather than to another individual. When the corporation purchases its own shares from the departing shareholder, the shares are said to be in the treasury.

Name: Equine Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes all revenues associated with diagnosing, hospitalizing and/or treating horses, including euthanasia (but, not mortuary services, which is account 4403).

Name: Farm Animal Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes all revenues associated with diagnosing, hospitalizing and/or treating large/farm animals, excluding horses, including euthanasia (but, not mortuary services, which is account 4403).

Name: Zoological Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes all revenues associated with diagnosing, hospitalizing and/or treating all zoological animals, including euthanasia (but, not mortuary services, which is account 4403).

Name: Exam/Diagnostic Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes outpatient exams, consultations and diagnostic services in the ER and any outpatient treatments. Euthanasia services are included in this account (do not include mortuary services; see account 4403).

Name: Hospitalization & Treatment Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes hospitalization (day or night), and inpatient services. Includes professional care, critical care, nursing care, oxygen, heat support, stomach tubing and lavage, enemas, continuous blood pressure monitoring, heartworm treatment support, tattoo services, bandages, casts, urinary catheterization, therapeutic abdominocentesis or thoracentesis, inpatient non-surgical wound care. Includes theriogenology services such as semen collection and preparation, insemination, obstetrical assistance, and neonatal care. Also includes Stem Cell Therapy.

Name: Emergency Surgery Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes Companion Animal Vaccine service income. Record in this account the fees charged and collected from administration of vaccines to immunize patients against disease. In the event that no physical exam fee or office charge fee is collected (or bundled with the vaccination service fee), then the entire fee is reported here. If vaccinations are given as part of an annual wellness program, the charge associated with vaccination should be recorded here if easily segregated by the VPIMS bundling option.

Name: Specialty Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes only those specialty services provided by a board-certified veterinarian with specialty credentials from an ABVS-recognized veterinary specialty organization. It would not include patient care, fluids, imaging, laboratory, diagnostics or dispending unless directly performed by the ophthalmologist. Subaccounts for specific specialist revenue (i.e. ophthalmology, internal medicine, oncology, etc.) can be created using accounts 5081 to 5094.

Name: Surgery
Description: This revenue center includes only those surgery services provided by a board-certified veterinarian with specialty credentials from an ABVS/AVMA-recognized veterinary surgery specialty organization. Services could be provided either by a traveling contract surgeon or a boarded staff surgeon if an employee of the practice. It should also include income from fees resulting from surgery room usage, surgical instrument or pack usage, surgical disposables and supplies (sutures, surgical drapes, gloves, etc.), surgeon fees, surgical implants, and plates and screws. Include orthopedic surgery, soft tissue surgery, and cryotherapy fee income, as well as laparoscopy and endoscopy income. If ovariohysterectomy (OHE/Spay), castration (neuter), and declaw procedures are bundled with anesthesia/analgesia as a single fee, the total fee charged should be included here.It would not include patient care, fluids, imaging, laboratory, diagnostics or dispending unless directly performed by the surgeon.

Name: Internal Medicine
Description: This revenue center includes only those internal medicine services provided by a board-certified veterinarian with specialty credentials from an ABVS/AVMA-recognized veterinary internal medicine specialty organization. It should also include income from fees resulting from related supplies and diagnostics associated with these internal medicine services.

Name: Cardiology
Description: This revenue center includes only those internal medicine services provided by a board-certified veterinarian with specialty credentials from an ABVS/AVMA-recognized veterinary internal medicine specialty organization with a focus on Cardiology. It should also include income from fees resulting from related supplies and diagnostics associated with these Cardiology services.

Name: Oncology, Medical
Description: This revenue center includes only those internal medicine services provided by a board-certified veterinarian with specialty credentials from an ABVS/AVMA-recognized veterinary internal medicine specialty organization with a focus on Medical (Chemotherapy) Oncology. It should also include income from fees resulting from related supplies and diagnostics associated with these Medical Oncological services.

Name: Oncology, Radiation
Description: This revenue center includes only those internal medicine services provided by a board-certified veterinarian with specialty credentials from an ABVS/AVMA-recognized veterinary internal medicine specialty organization with a focus on Radiation Oncology. It should also include income from fees resulting from related supplies and diagnostics associated with these Radiation Oncological services.

Name: Neurology
Description: This revenue center includes only those internal medicine services provided by a board-certified veterinarian with specialty credentials from an ABVS/AVMA-recognized veterinary internal medicine specialty organization with a focus on Neurology. It should also include income from fees resulting from related supplies and diagnostics associated with these Neurology services.

Name: Ophthalmology
Description: This revenue center includes only those ophthalmology services provided by a board-certified veterinarian with specialty credentials from an ABVS/AVMA-recognized veterinary ophthalmology specialty organization. It should also include income from fees resulting from related supplies and diagnostics associated with these ophthalmological medicine services.

Name: Dermatology
Description: This revenue center includes only those dermatology services provided by a board-certified veterinarian with specialty credentials from an ABVS/AVMA-recognized veterinary dermatology specialty organization. It should also include income from fees resulting from related supplies and diagnostics associated with these dermatological medicine services.

Name: Dentistry
Description: This revenue center includes income from fees from dental prophylaxis. Also includes income from extractions, orthodontics, endodontics, and products applied to teeth or defects in the dental operatory. Includes oral surgery related to dental procedures such as gingival flaps etc.

Name: Radiology, Diagnostic
Description: This revenue center includes all revenues associated with diagnostic radiology.

Name: Anesthesia/Pain Management
Description: This revenue center includes income from fees from gas or IV anesthesia charged as a service. Includes all anesthetic “cocktails” & sedations (injectables such as Midazolam, Fentanyl, Marcaine, Bupivicaine, DexDormitor, Dormisedan, Telazole, Lidocaine, Propofol, Alfaxan, etc.), epidural nerve blocks, local & dental nerve blocks. Also includes income from anesthetic monitoring. Does not include tranquilizers

Name: Alternative/Acupuncture
Description: This revenue center includes fees related to income from chiropractic, acupuncture and homeopathy services. Alternative medical products sold should be captured in 4532 -- OTC Nutriceuitical Revenue.

Name: Behavior
Description: This revenue center includes fees related to behavior service income and includes both services related to the prevention of behavior issues that might lead to owner-pet bond breakage (behavior wellness), or consulting services addressing the modification of existing behavior issues (separation anxiety, excessive vocalization, aggression, and destructive behavior). Medications and OTC products to treat behavioral issues should be included under Pharmacy – 5105 (FDA) or Ancillary – 5801 (OTC).

Name: Rehabilitiation Therapy
Description: This revenue center includes fees from activities involving treadmill, swimming, core muscle conditioning, massage, and similar physiotherapeutic applications to increase muscle strength, range of joint motion, flexibility, and mobility.

Name: Nutrition
Description: This revenue center includes all revenues associated with nutirition diagnositcs, consultation and treatment..

Name: Avian/Exotics
Description: This revenue center includes all revenues associated with treatment of birds, repitles and other exotic animals.

Name: Diagnostic Lab / Clinical Pathology
Description: This revenue center includes all revenues associated with diagnostics in clinical pathology.

Name: Theriogenology
Description: This revenue center includes all revenues associated with reproductive health and breeding of animals.

Name: X-Ray Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes fees for radiographs and interpretation of radiographic studies, including Penn Hip and OFA fees. Radiograph revenue associated with dental procedures should be included in account 5404.

Name: Dental X-Ray Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes fees related to income from dental radiographs and interpretation fees.

Name: CT Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes income from fees derived from image studies via computerized tomography technology, and including any interpretation fees, whether or not bundled with the procedure fee.

Name: Ultrasound Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes income from fees derived from ultrasound imaging procedures and their interpretation. Include income for needle aspirate along with ultrasound guided fine needle and Trucut biopsies procedure fees. Ultrasound guided urine cystocentesis fees should be included in lab services account 5301.

Name: MRI Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes income from fees derived from MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) scan procedures, and study interpretation.

Name: In-House Laboratory Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes fees related to in-house laboratory includes any pre-surgical operatory tests, CBCs (complete blood counts), serum/blood chemistries, urinalyses, fecal analyses, cytology analyses, and semen evaluations completed by practice employees using practice laboratory equipment and supplies. Skin scraping, phlebotomy, blind or ultrasound guided cystocentesis, or fine needle aspirate fees resulting from specimen collection (chemistry, cytology, and/or biopsy interpretation) should be included in this account.

Name: Outside Laboratory Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes fees related to income from outside lab tests such as state diagnostic labs, private reference labs such as Antech, IDEXX, Marshfield, Phoenix, Abaxis etc. Includes phlebotomy and urine collection fees including cystocentesis for urine testing, histopathology and necropsy fees when performed by an outside lab.

Name: Outside Radiology (Imaging) Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes all fees related to radiological 3rd party overreads and consultations (of Xrays, etc).

Name: Mortuary/Disposal Services
Description: This revenue center includes fees related to cremation, burial income, and related body care services. Include fee income for sales of cemetery plots, caskets, urns, paw prints, and associated patient memorial services or products. (Euthanasia procedure fees are included in account 5010 – Exam Revenue).

Name: FDA Prescription Medication Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes revenue from the sale of FDA prescription medications such as pills, capsules, liquids, and any other FDA approved product category not listed in the 5100 to 5199 accounts.

Name: Injection Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes income from FDA inpatient and outpatient injections and any injection fee and any associated packaging/dispensing/injection fees. Insulin, tranquilizers and Immiticide are included in this account. Does not include income from injections for anesthetics, euthanasia solutions, sedating agents, Proheart and Program.

Name: Flea-Tick Non-HW Parasite Control Medication Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes income from FDA prescription products that prevent fleas and/or ticks, but not heartworms. Example: Comfortis, Program, NexGard & Bravecto.

Name: HW Parasite Control Medication Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes income from any FDA product that prevents heartworms or combo HW and other internal or external parasites. Example: Sentinel, Trifexis, Heartguard, Advantage Multi, Revolution, Proheart-6, etc.

Name: Internet Pharmacy Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes the gross revenues resulting from sales made through a practice web portal, regardless of type of product, and whether or not sales are facilitated through a subcontracted vendor (VetSource, MyVetDirect, etc.) Also include income from products billed by the practice, but shipped directly to the client. Ancillary products may be split out if desired and put in the ancillary category (5804).

Name: Therapeutic Dietary Product Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes fees related to any food that is sold as a medical recommendation to support a patient suffering from a diagnosed specific medical health problem. Hint: while often called prescription diets they do not by law require a veterinarian to prescribe them but manufacturers do frequently limit their sales through veterinarians and veterinary hospitals.

Name: Retail Dietary Product Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes fees related to any food that is sold as a wellness/maintenance diet, pediatric diet or traditional food WITHOUT a specific therapeutic dietary formulation for a diagnosed medical health problem.

Name: OTC Shampoo
Description: This revenue center includes income from feesfrom shampoos including non-FDA shampoos and flea shampoos

Name: OTC Nutriceutical
Description: This revenue center includes income from fees from OTC/Nutraceuticals - all therapeutic over-the-counter (non- prescription) products, including Chinese herbs and homeopathic products, dental hygiene products including Greenies and chews and nutraceuticals, probiotics, vitamins. Also includes Elizabethan anti-self-mutilation type collars, behavior modifying non-FDA therapeutics and other products used in behavior therapy, including Soft Paws and Thundershirts.

Name: Pet Supplies
Description: This revenue center includes income from fees income from non-therapeutic, retail sales of leashes, harnesses, collars, toys, point of purchase items, brushes, flea combs, grooming sprays, candles, milk replacers, pet treats, deodorants, nail trimmers, pet carriers, pet ID tags, pill cutters, cat litter, etc. Includes city and county license tags.

Name: OTC Flea-Tick Control Product
Description: This revenue center includes income from fees from EPA non-FDA flea control products such as topical application products (Frontline, Activyl, Vectra, Certifect, Cheristin, etc.), non-FDA oral flea treatments such as Capstar, flea sprays, powders, dips, and premise treatments.

Name: Internet Ancillary Product
Description: Include in this revenue center income from fees related to internet ancillary product sales if you wish to separate them from pharmacy items. Otherwise put everything under Pharmacy (see above 4515 Internet Pharmacy Revenue).

Name: Boarding/Daycare Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes income from fees from boarding and daycare services. If revenues from daycare services are substantial, a separate subaccount of boarding income can be used. If hospital housing is required due to medical condition treatment, doctor observation and nursing need, use hospitalization account 5020.

Name: Grooming Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes income from bathing & grooming services and associated anal sac expression and nail trim procedures, when bundled and provided by grooming personnel. Do not include fees related to treatment of medical conditions discovered during grooming services, such as ear care. If anesthesia or sedation is required to perform grooming services, these procedures are coded to anesthesia account 5600 unless bundled with grooming.

Name: Wellness Program Revenue
Description: This revenue center includes all wellness program revenues (typically recurring monthly revenues) for non-medical health and nutrition

Name: Fee Discounts
Description: This revenue center includes client and employee discounts and fee accommodations are posted to this account. In the veterinary profession, the level of fee discounting can be relatively significant. For this reason, discounts are recorded as a debit directly offsetting operational revenues, so that management has an improved awareness of discounting impact on overall cost of operations. When offset against gross revenues charged, discounts reduce the total operating revenue figure that is used to calculate each expense as a percent of it. One challenge is that all fee discounts are not recorded in practice records. Many times, veterinarians provide free services (either intentionally or accidentally) that are never shown on the practice’s records, thus understating the true level of client discounts. This oversight creates yet another problem: no recorded history of what was done for the patient exists.

Name: Returns & Allowances
Description: Returns and allowances are fee amounts the practice returns to clients for disputed work, such as when a client is billed twice for the same procedure or when a client returns dispensed product they believe is not efficacious. The practice bookkeeper prepares a check or other payment to the client as settlement. This account carries a debit balance and as such, is an offsetting account to revenues (revenue accounts normally carry a credit balance). Transaction postings to this account decrease the practice gross revenue.

Name: Relief Emergency Professional Service Costs
Description: Cost of 1099 or locum emergency doctors, whether full-time or part-time

Name: Radiology Professional Service Costs
Description: Cost of 1099 radiologists performing work on premises

Name: SurgicalProfessional Service Costs
Description: Cost of 1099 surgeons performing work on premises

Name: Other Specialty Professional Service Costs
Description: Cost of other types of specialists operating as 1099 contractors performing work on premises

Name: X-Ray Cost
Description: Variable cost of x-Rays performed

Name: Dental X-Ray Cost
Description: Variable cost of dental x-Rays performed

Name: CT Cost
Description: Variable cost of CT scans performed

Name: Ultrasound Cost
Description: Variable cost of ultrasounds performed

Name: MRI Cost
Description: Variable cost of MRIs performed

Name: In-House Laboratory Costs
Description: Cost of any lab supplies, reagents or expendables along with minor non-depreciable equipment used in performing in-house lab testing. Does not include cost of significant equipment repairs, maintenance and service agreements which should be expensed separately under 7520 Maintenance, 7530 Service Contracts or 7570 Repairs. New capital equipment over $500 should be entered as an asset & depreciated.

Name: Outside Laboratory Costs
Description: Cost of supplies or charges by reference lab for performing outside lab testing, histopathology and necropsy. Includes cost of mailing samples to lab. Includes consulting fees by lab pathologist.

Name: Outside Radiology (Imaging) Costs
Description: Charges related to radiological 3rd party overreads and consultations (of Xrays, sonograms, MRI's, CT's etc).

Name: Mortuary/Cremation/Disposal Services
Description: Charges paid to 3rd parties related to the disposal of and/or mortuary services for deceased animals.

Name: General Medical Supplies
Description: Cost of general medical supplies, such as gauze, tape, sutures, IV fulids, etc

Name: Blood Products
Description: Cost of blood products

Name: Surgical Supplies
Description: Cost of surgical supplies, such as screws, plates, etc.

Name: Laboratory Supplies
Description: Cost of  all in-house lab supplies, including reagents, etc.

Name: Oxygen Supplies
Description: Cost of oxygen cannisters and/or oxygen generators (amortized).

Name: Dermatological Supplies
Description: Cost of dermatological supplies used for in-hospital treatments, including creams, etc. (those solf to customers are included in either prescription or OTC product costs)

Name: Oncology Supplies
Description: Cost of medical oncological supplies used for in-hospital treatments, including chemotherapy supplies.

Name: Other Specialty Supplies
Description: Cost of specialty supplies not captured in the other accounts, perhaps including ophthalmological supplies.

Name: Digital COGS Supplies or Services
Description: Payments to 3rd parties for digital supplies and/or services associated with costs of goods sold, such as "health certificates" for customers, or management of regulatory (SDS filings, etc) requirements, or any royalties/fees paid to distribution channels as a % of revenue they generate

Name: FDA Prescription Medication Costs
Description: FDA prescription medications such as pills, capsules, liquids, and any other FDA approved product category not listed in the 6100 to 6199 accounts. Also include pharmacy dispensing supplies such as prescription containers and labels.

Name: Injection Costs
Description: Includes all FDA injectable medications billed as pharmacy injection income. It does include insulin and Immiticide injections.

Name: Flea-Tick Non-HW Parasite Control Medication Cost
Description: Includes FDA prescription products that prevent fleas and/or ticks, but not heartworm. Examples: Comfortis, Program, Nexgard, Bravecto etc.

Name: HW Parasite Control Medication Cost
Description: Includes purchases of any FDA product that prevents heartworms or combination products that prevent heartworms and other internal or external parasites. Examples: Sentinel, Trifexis, Heartguard, Advantage Multi, Revolution, Proheart-6, etc.

Name: Internet Pharmacy Cost
Description: Includes cost of products resulting in sales made through a web portal either belonging to the practice or a subcontracted vendor such as VetSource, Vet Centric, MyVetDirect or Henry Schein portal. The practice may split out ancillary products if they desire and expense separately to 6804 Ancillary Internet Costs. Subcontracted vendors usually pay the practice the net amount of sales made to clients, so a journal entry may be required to record sales at gross (in account 5130) and the related cost here.

Name: Therapeutic Dietary Product Cost
Description: Cost of pet foods that are sold as a therapeutic medical recommendation to address a patient’s diagnosed medical health.

Name: Retail Dietary Product Cost
Description: Cost of pet foods that are sold as a wellness/maintenance diet, pediatric diet or traditional food WITHOUT a specific therapeutic dietary formulation for a diagnosed medical health problem.

Name: OTC Shampoo
Description: Includes all therapeutic OTC products, probiotics, dental hygiene OTC products including Greenies, nutraceuticals, vitamins, alternative medicine and acupuncture products such as needles and Chinese herbs, Elizabethan self- mutilation type collars, non-FDA shampoos, behavior modifying products used in behavior therapy including Soft Paws and Thunder Shirts.

Name: OTC Nutriceutical
Description: Includes all therapeutic OTC products, probiotics, dental hygiene OTC products including Greenies, nutraceuticals, vitamins, alternative medicine and acupuncture products such as needles and Chinese herbs, Elizabethan self- mutilation type collars, non-FDA shampoos, behavior modifying products used in behavior therapy including Soft Paws and Thunder Shirts.

Name: Pet Supplies
Description: Include all retail costs of product sold in hospital. May include all non-medical products such as leashes, harnesses, collars, toys, point of purchase items, brushes, flea combs, grooming sprays, candles, milk replacers, pet treats, Pill Pockets, deodorants, nail trimmers, pet carriers, pet ID tags, pill cutters, air fresheners, etc. Include city/county license tags in this account.

Name: OTC Flea-Tick Control Product
Description: Include all EPA non-FDA flea control products such as topically applied products (Frontline, Activyl, Vectra, Certifect, Cheristin, etc.), Capstar, sprays, powders, dips, and premise treatments. Flea shampoos are all in 6801 OTC Products, Shampoos & Nutraceutical Costs.

Name: Internet Ancillary Product
Description: Record costs in this account resulting from ancillary product sales made through a practice web portal. If not separated from Internet pharmacy costs, include all in account number 6130 Internet Pharmacy Costs.

Name: Boarding Cost
Description: Food, bedding, food/water bowls and kitty litter pans and litter used exclusively for the maintenance of boarded or hospitalized animals. Include any other expense you know to be only for boarded pets and not comingled with other areas of the hospital.

Name: Grooming Cost
Description: Include all supplies for the grooming and bathing of pets in the hospital. May include gallon sized grooming shampoos and supplies used by groomers.

Name: Salary Expense
Description: All salaries exclude the amounts earned, but reserved for sick time, vacation time, but include the portions of salaries withheld for garnishments, which should appears onteh balance sheet to the extent they are payable.

Name: Diagnostic Lab / Clinical Pathology Doctor Salary
Diagnostic Lab / Clinical Pathology Technician Salary
Client Service Representative ("CSR") Salary Expense
Description: Gross wages, commissions, and/or bonuses for receptionists and client service representatives (CSRs).

Name: Management Salary Expense
Description: Gross wages, commissions, and/or bonuses for employees managing the practice

Name: Adminstrative Salary Expense
Description: Gross wages, commissions, and/or bonuses for employees providing predominantly administrative, managerial, or back office services.

Name: Maintenance Salary Expense
Description: Gross wages, commissions, and/or bonuses for employees performing janatorial and building maintenance work.

Name: Groomer Compensation Expense
Description: Gross wages, commissions, and/or bonuses for pet groomers.

Name: Boarding Staff Compensation Expense
Description: Gross wages, commissions, and/or bonuses for boarding/kennel staff.

Name: Owner Compensation Expense
Description: The gross amount (before tax withholdings) of salaries, wages, bonuses, commissions, and guaranteed payments paid to owner-employees post to this account. LLC member distributions, partner draws, and sole proprietor draws are recorded in accounts 3204, 3304 and 3403. Each veterinarian employee-owner can be listed individually with a sub-account (7001, 7002, etc.) if desired for additional detail within financial reports. This account should include the wages paid to owner veterinarians for clinical time (excludes compensation for management time which should be expensed in 7005 Owner Management Compensation).

Name: FICA Tax Expense -- Employers Portion
Description: This account expenses the employer’s portion of social security (OASDI) and Medicare tax matching funds (to those withheld from employee wages).

Name: Federal Unemployment Tax Expense
Description: Employers must pay federal taxes to fund unemployment claims. The unemployment tax amounts required by state law are coded to the next account.

Name: State Unemployment Tax Expense
Description: Employers must pay state taxes to fund unemployment claims. The unemployment tax amounts required by federal law are coded to the prior account.

Name: Other Employer Payroll Tax Expense
Description: Some states require other tax payments by employers, and these more unique employment tax payments should be coded to this account.

Name: Group Health Insurance Premium
Description: Payments made to cover the employer portion of the cost of Group Health Insurance Plans for employees

Name: S-Corporation Shareholder Health Insurance Premium
Description: Payments made to cover the shareholder portion of the cost of Group Health Insurance Plans for shareholders

Name: Group Dental/Vision Insurance Premium Expense
Description: Payments made to cover the employer portion of the cost of Group Dental/Vision Insurance plans for employees

Name: Group Disability Insurance Premium Expense
Description: Payments made to cover the employer portion of the cost of Group Disability Insurance Plans for employees

Name: Group Term Life Insurance Premium Expense
Description: Payments made to cover the employer portion of the cost of Group Life Insurance Plans for key employees

Name: Employer Retirement Plan (e.g. 401(k)) Contribution Expense
Description: Payments made by the employer as contributions to theretirement plan for all employees (matching payments, etc)

Name: Profit-Sharing Expense
Description: Standard profit-sharing bonuses across a wide section of employees, rather than employee-specific bonuses (which would be listed in salary expense)

Name: Sick Pay
Description: Payments made to employees for time they were sick and unable to work

Name: Vacation Pay
Description: Payments made to employees for "paid vacation" time

Name: Professional Liability Insurance Expense
Description: Premiums paid for insurance to cover PLIT (Professional Liability Insurance) for doctors

Name: Workers Compensation Insurance Expense
Description: Tax or premiums paid for practice insurance that manages the risk of claims related to employee injury on the job, and provides wage replacement and medical benefits in exchange for mandatory relinquishment of the employee’s right to sue the employer for negligence. Direct payment for small dollar value medical payments related to on the job injuries in order to mitigate workers’ comp.

Name: Employment Practices Liability Insurance Expense
Description: Premiums paid for insurance to cover Employment Practices Liability Insurance

Name: Continuing Education Expense
Description: Payments made to enroll employees in webinars, seminars, conferences and conventions for the purposes of expanding skills and knowledge, as well as complying with regulatory guidelines to maintain professional licensure in that particular state.

Name: Registration Fees
Description: Registration fees for conferences or other symposia, whether physical or virtual

Name: Educational Materials Expense
Description: Payments made to purchase materials (books, trade magazines, conference materials, etc) related to continuing education

Name: Staff Training Fees & Costs
Description: Payments made to facilitate internal staff training

Name: Common Carrier Travel
Keywords: Airline, airfare, train ticket, bus ticket
Description: Payments made to purchase plane tickets, train tickets, bus tickets, baggage fees, etc for buisness-related travel

Name: Lodging
Description: Payments made for accomodiations for buisness-related travel

Name: Ground Transportation
Description: Payments made rental cars or taxis/Ubers for buisness-related travel

Name: Mileage Reimbursement (eg for CE travel)
Description: Payments made to reimburse employees for their use of their own vehicles for buisness-related travel, including for parking

Name: Study Group Fees (e.g., VMG)
Description: This account includes annual dues/expenses, quarterly fees, travel expenses, hotel/lodging expenses, materials & production expenses associated with study groups.

Name: Employee Business Meals & Entertainment
Description: Expense amounts paid for feeding employees who are working on behalf of the practice to recruit new employees or clients, gain training, improving skills, networking, meeting, etc.

Name: Staff Events & Recreation
Description: Expenditures coded to this account typically include staff picnics and holiday parties, but can include other practice financial support of events wherein 100% of all current employees are invited and included in the event.

Name: Employee Recruitment
Description: Expenses coded to this account may include the cost of background checks, pre-employment drug screening, reimbursed airfare for purpose of interview visits, reimbursed moving expenses, etc.

Name: Laundry & Uniform
Description: Expenses related to the purhase or cleaning of uniforms for staff

Name: Employee Gifts
Description: Expenses related to the purhase of gifts or gift cards for staff

Name: Remote Storage Expense
Description: Payments made to rent off-premises storage space are coded to this account.

Name: Building Maintenance
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to maintain the building on an a la carte basis (rather than as a fixed price service contract)

Name: Building Service Contract
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to maintain the building as part of a service contract

Name: Facility Repairs
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to repair Facilities

Name: Janatorial/Cleaning Expense
Description: This account includes payments to a contracted cleaning, maid, or janitorial service as well as supplies associated with facility cleaning.

Name: Environmental Control
Description: This account includes payments to a pest or mold control companies servicing the facilities

Name: Equipment Rental Expense
Description: This account includes one-time equipment rental fees, such as a pressure washer to clean the practice facility. Operating lease payments (non-purchase leases) should also be included here. Many leases are purchases in disguise and should be capitalized to the 2000 account series with an associated liability included in the 3030 account series. Talk with the practice’s CPA to ensure proper accounting of the practice’s leases.

Name: Minor Equipment Purchase Expense
Description: Payments made to purchase minor equipment (typically less than $300).

Name: Medical Equipment Maintenance
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to maintain Medical Equipment on an a la carte basis (rather than as a fixed price service contract)

Name: Lab Equipment Maintenance
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to maintain Lab Equipment on an a la carte basis (rather than as a fixed price service contract)

Name: Office Equipment Maintenance
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to maintain Office Equipment on an a la carte basis (rather than as a fixed price service contract)

Name: Computer/IT Equipment Maintenance
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to maintain Computer/IT Equipment on an a la carte basis (rather than as a fixed price service contract)

Name: Medical Equipment Service Contract
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to maintain Medical Equipment as part of a service contract

Name: Lab Equipment Service Contract
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to maintain Lab Equipment as part of a service contract

Name: Office Equipment Service Contract
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to maintain Office Equipment as part of a service contract

Name: Computer/IT Equipment Service Contract
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to maintain Computer/IT Equipment as part of a service contract

Name: Medical Equipment Repairs
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to repair Medical Equipment

Name: Lab Equipment Repairs
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to repair Lab Equipment

Name: Office Equipment Repairs
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to repair Office Equipment

Name: Computer/IT Equipment Repairs
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties to repair Computer/IT Equipment

Name: Real Estate/Property Tax Expense
Description: The lease agreement and who owns practice real estate makes determination of whether the practice or the landlord pays real estate taxes.

Name: Personal Property Tax Expense
Description: Record tangible and intangible personal property tax payments in this account, when applicable in your practice’s state. See account 3420 Accrued Property Tax for additional explanation.

Name: Practice Vehicle Expense
Description: Costs associated with running and maintaining a practice vehicle for business purposes should be coded here, including gasoline/diesel, vehicle repairs and maintenance, vehicle insurance, and vehicle license renewals. If the vehicle is leased, lease payments are classed here.

Name: Electricity
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties for electricity

Name: Natural Gas/Oil/Propane
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties for fossil fuels

Name: Water
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties for water or water/sewer (they are sometimes combined on a single bill by the utility)

Name: Sewer
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties for sewer, if separately paid

Name: Garbage Removal
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties for ordinary refuse removal (not to include mortuary)

Name: Landline Voice
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties for landline voice services

Name: Mobile Voice
Description: Payments made to 3rd parties for mobile voice/internet services

Name: Licenses & Permits
Description: Include expenditures for professional and business licenses and permits, such as veterinary and technician license fees, DEA licenses, building occupancy permits, and kennel permits.

Name: Use Tax
Description: Use tax paid on applicable purchases can be allocated to the appropriate expense category rather than using this account, if you prefer.

Name: Franchise Tax
Description: Record state franchise, commercial activity, or other similar state tax payments to this account.

Name: Other Tax
Description: Use this account to record other taxes levied on the practice that do not appropriately fit elsewhere. Note well: payroll taxes, workers compensation premiums/tax, corporate income taxes, real estate taxes, personal property taxes, etc. should all be coded elsewhere.

Name: Veterinary & Professional Dues/Licenses
Description: Expense to this account expenditure made for AVMA, AAHA, VHMA, state and local associations, and business associations such as chamber of commerce membership dues.

Name: Subscriptions
Description: Expense to this account recurring expenditures (even if prepaid, as with software licenses) made for subscriptions for periodicals and/or software (& cloud-based services) used by the business that cannot be directly linked to revenue generation

Name: Client Education Material
Description: Use this account to expense newsletters, brochures, other client education materials, and postage related to newsletter mailings.

Name: Business Gifts
Description: Gifts, flowers, cards, food baskets, sympathy cards and expression of sympathy gifts.

Name: Charitable Contributions
Description: Record payments made to qualified charitable organizations to this account only if no current or future practice promotional benefit is received. If such donations have promotional and marketing benefit that advances client acquisition and growth, then consider classing such payments as advertising and marketing expense, even if made to qualified charitable organizations. If you received a direct benefit, such as a meal, then the fair market value of the direct benefit should be coded to the appropriate account (7440, in this example), with the difference coded to charitable contributions. For example, if the practice pays $100 to a qualified charitable organization and in return receives a meal with a value of $20, then of the $100 expense, $80 should be coded to account 7740 and $20 should be coded to account 7440, assuming there is a business purpose for attendance and business discussion relative to the practice.

Name: Computer Supplies
Description: Post transactions for peripheral supplies such as cables and small dollar-value software to this account. Minor equipment and software acquisitions may be expensed to this account in accord with the practice capitalization policy. Major acquisitions of computer systems, software, or environmental changes should be capitalized and posted to account 2050 Computer. Labor costs associated with the installation of hardware or software should also be capitalized as part of the respective computer hardware or software account.

Name: Office Supplies
Description: Expenditures in this account include typical general office supplies such as pens, paper, paper and binder clips, binders, paper files, inexpensive calculators and small equipment.

Name: Postage & Delivery
Description: Expense to this account stamps, FedEx and UPS, parcel post, courier service, and postal machine rental. Postage for newsletters and other promotional items should be recorded in the appropriate category. Semen shipping freight costs should be included with artificial insemination (A.I.) costs in account 6020.

Name: Printing & Reproduction
Description: Post costs for printing in-office documents and using outside printing services (e.g. Staples or FedEx Office).

Name: Business Services
Description: Payments to business services companies, incuding credit socring vendors, for non-recurring busienss services

Name: Accounting Fees
Description: Record fees paid to accounting firms for accounting and tax services. Payroll service and/or outside bookkeeping service payments are coded to the following two accounts.

Name: Bookkeeping Services
Description: Payments for an independent bookkeeper who is not an employee of the practice are included here. If the bookkeeper is an employee of the practice, wages would be recorded in account 7166.

Name: Payroll Service Fees
Description: Post payments to this account for an independent payroll company service involving preparation of employee paychecks, payroll-related tax returns and filings, and tax fund remittance handling, such as ADP, Paychex, Heartland, or Intuit, among many others.

Name: Employe Benefits / Pension Administration
Description: This account includes fees paid to a third-party administrator for maintenance of retirement plans (e.g. 401K, SIMPLE IRA, etc.) or other employee benefit plan maintenance, such as Section 125 Cafeteria Plans. Surety bond premium expense is also coded to this account.

Name: Legal Services Fees
Description: This account is used for expenses related to ordinary and necessary business expenses related to attorney and legal assistance. Expenses related to business startup, business organization, and business acquisition generally are NOT coded to this account. Special attention must be given to the exact legal services incurred to determine how they should be handled for accounting and tax purposes. These issues are beyond the scope of this handbook, and the practice accountant should be assisting in determination of correct handling.

Name: Professional / Business Consulting Fees
Description: Code payments to third party companies and independent contractors for business management advice and consultation services.

Name: General Liability Insurance Expense
Description: Code premium expenses for liability insurance on the facility, inventory, contents, and business overhead insurance (BOI; sometimes called disability overhead insurance).

Name: Flood Insurance Expense
Description: Code premium expenses for flood insurance on the facility, inventory and contents

Name: Yellow Page Advertising
Description: Payments made to advertise in phone directories, including the "yellow pages."

Name: Website Maintenance
Description: Payments made to vendors to maintain the practice website on its servers or the cloud, including payments made to hosting services, such as AWS.

Name: Internet Advertising
Description: Payments made to vendors to display advertising via the Internet/Web.

Name: Direct Mailing
Description: Payments made to vendors to utilize physical direct mail or email campaigns to market to customers, including such services as SurveyMonkey, MailChimp, etc.

Name: Client Reminders
Description: Payments made to vendors to generate automated client reminders

Name: Memorial Contributions
Description: Payments made in memory of any party, the payment of which establishes some community goodwill and/or awareness.

Name: Sponsored Events
Description: Payments made to sponsor any party, the payment of which establishes some community goodwill and/or awareness.

Name: Marketing Consulting Fees
Description: Payments made to any outside marketing consultant that assists in the development of marketing campaign plans and execution.

Name: Advertising & Promotion -- Other
Description: Payments made to vendors to advertise in offline advertising and/or promotional events.

Name: Bank Charges & Service Fees
Description: Code payments made for bank and financial management service fees for processing deposits and bounced checks, TeleCheck, maintaining an account or safe deposit box, and providing other services. Also include fees for late credit card payments.

Name: Merchant Services Fees / Credit Card Discounts
Description: The account records the fees paid to credit card companies, by way of discounts, on payments received from such companies on behalf of customers making payment for services/products.

Name: Care Credit/TeleCheck Service Fees
Description: This account records the fees paid to CareCredit related to client use of the instant credit system to pay practice invoices. Other instant consumer credit vehicles the practice contracts would result in fees that can be expensed to this account, as well.

Name: Collection Fees
Description: This account includes fees paid to a collection agency for pursuit of client accounts receivable.

Name: Bad Debt Expense
Description: Bad debt expense is recorded at the time of direct write-off of specific client accounts receivable that have been pursued and collection efforts exhausted. This account will be used by accrual basis taxpayers.

Name: Returned Check Fees
Description: Record check payments received from clients that did not clear the bank due to insufficient fund balances or were otherwise returned as uncollected by the practice’s bank. If another means of payment is received from the client to settle the returned check, the payment should be offset here. If a re-deposited check successfully clears, then the second deposit is recorded against this account, effectively clearing it to zero. The balance of this account will only include returned checks for which no compensating payment has been received. This account will be used by cash basis taxpayers

Name: Depreciation Expense
Description: If your practice does not have depreciation adjustments via its tax accountant, estimates for interim, non-tax reporting purposes can be made as follows, at ownership prerogative: Spread the cost of fixed asset costs (account 2000-2499) over a 10-year estimated useful life.

Name: Amortization Expense
Description: The periodic expense attributed to the decline in usefulness of an intangible asset. Similar to depreciation, it is the process of gradually reducing the value of an asset over its useful life, to reflect an estimate of its use in producing revenues over many financial periods.

Name: Rent Revenue
Description: Post interest income from all sources, including notes receivable and interest-bearing investment accounts to this account. If a variety of interest-bearing investments exists, each interest source can be separately presented by establishing individual interest-revenue account codes to match with the Forms 1099 – INT the practice will receive in the first quarter of the subsequent calendar year.

Name: Miscellaneous Revenue
Description: Use this account to report episodic revenue for which there is no other classification. For example, an insurance payment received for damaged property in excess of its repair costs would be recorded here.

Name: Miscellaneous Expense
Description: In this section, record non-recurring expenses unrelated to daily veterinary practice operations. Do not post operating expenses to this account.

Name: Fines & Penalties
Description: Fines and penalties such as those related to late submission of tax filings or traffic tickets are coded to this category, and are non-tax-deductible by law.

Name: Officer/Key Person Life Insurance
Description: Premiums for practice-owned life insurance on the life of a key person(s) for which the practice is also the beneficiary are coded to this account.

Name: Officer Disability Insurance
Description: Premiums for any long- or short- term disability insurance provided for a key person(s) nby the practice are coded to this account.

Name: Debt Interest Expense -- 3rd Party
Description: This account records the interest expense portion of debt service payments to financial institutions. The portion of payment related to principal reduction is coded to the corresponding loan account in the practice liability 3000 series.

Name: Debt Interest Expense -- Shareholder/Owner
Description: This account is used to record interest paid on practice debt owed to shareholders or other related parties. See liability account 3050.

Name: Other Interest Expense
Description: This account records the interest expense payments related to vendor and other debt, interest assessed on outstanding credit card liability.

Name: SBA Funding Fees
Description: Fees paid to the SBA to support an SBA loan where interest expense is paid to a third party financial institution

Name: Federal Income Tax Expense
Description: Record here the federal income tax liability associated with the practice entity’s taxable income, which must be paid by the entity. Taxes owed by practice owners are not recorded on the practice’s books. This tax is not a payroll tax.

Name: State Income Tax Expense
Description: Record here the state income tax liability associated with the practice entity’s taxable income, which must be paid by the entity. Taxes owed by practice owners are not recorded on the practice’s books. This tax is not a payroll tax.

Name: Local Income Tax Expense
Description: Record here the city, regional, or other local income tax liability associated with the practice entity’s taxable income, that must be paid by the entity. Taxes owed by practice owners are not recorded on the practice’s books. This tax is not a payroll tax.
